header.title: A DRACONIAN EGYPTIAN GRIMOIRE
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Draconian Magic, Egyptian Magic, Grimoire Traditions

central_thesis: This grimoire aims to bridge ancient Egyptian magical practices from the pre-dynastic 'draconian Egypt' era with modern Draconian Left Hand Path traditions. It provides practical rituals for self-initiation, empowerment, and gnosis through direct engagement with specific Egyptian deities and thoughtforms, emphasizing the primal, dark, and often overlooked African roots of Egyptian spirituality and presenting a holistic understanding of their true magical mechanics.

structure_content.chapter_title: Prelude: The Roots of the Draconian Egypt Tradition
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the Draconian tradition within an ancient Egyptian context, tracing its historical roots from 11000 BCE through pre-dynastic sites like Bir Kiseiba and Nabta Playa. It details the profound influence of various African tribes (San, Nama, Hadza, Pygmies, Sandawe, Dogon, Berber) on early Egyptian spiritual practices, including spirit work, cyclical reality, divination, ecstatic trance, and funerary rites. The text establishes the 'draconian period' as a lunar-yoni paradigm, emphasizing its raw, primal, and Setian aspects, preceding the rise of the solar-phallic paradigm around 3800 BCE with the star Thuban (Alpha Draconis) as the North Pole Star. It clarifies neters as personifications of primal natural forces and elders of the pantheon, highlighting the evolving and synthesizing nature of beliefs leading up to the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt.

Anpu (Anubis) is presented as the original Egyptian Lord of the Dead, a psychopomp, and master of embalming, whose role shifted over centuries. The chapter provides a 3-day ritual cycle for self-dedication to Anpu's mysteries, including a 'Dedication to Exploration' (pledging commitment with blood anointing), an 'Evocation of Anpu' (to visible appearance using scrying for a personalized link), and 'Anpu’s Temple/Dream Working' (visiting his temple for insight on one's path). The focus is on finding correct paths and deeper draconian wisdom.

Set is described as the god of change, the desert, storms, and chaos, an initiator who clears paths through destruction and teaches self-reliance. His earlier, less demonized draconian role is emphasized, removing later familial links. A 3-day ritual is provided: 'Desert Initiation' (purification through simulated desert heat and light to receive gnosis), 'Set the Elder' (communing with Set as a sage in a cave visualization for nightside knowledge), and 'The Throne Room of Set' (negotiating with Lord Set for riches and gratification within a vivid throne room visualization).

Ma'at represents cosmic order, balance, and justice, a principle rooted in African concepts of oneness. Her role in the weighing of the heart ceremony is highlighted. A 3-day ritual focuses on harmonizing with her energies: 'Harmonizing with Ma’at' (meditating on a grey feather at twilight for insight into life imbalances), 'Petitioning Ma’at' (presenting a written petition for balance and justice), and 'Purification through Ma’at' (reciting 42 negative confessions as a sacrifice to purify oneself for manifestations, with a 28-day pledge to avoid them).

The Sphinx is explored as a keeper of secrets and an embodiment of the 'four powers' (To Know, To Will, To Dare, To Keep Silent), drawing from both ancient Egyptian mystery and later Greek/Western occult interpretations (Eliphas Levi). A 5-day ritual series helps practitioners develop these powers: 'To Know' (pledging to learn a new subject), 'To Will' (consecrating a talisman to achieve one's Will), 'To Dare' (evoking a chosen spirit to visible appearance for assistance, with detailed instructions on ritual circles and triangles of art), 'To Keep Silent' (pledging not to reveal ritual intent), and 'The Hidden Chamber' (invoking Tehuti to reveal cosmic secrets through meditation).

Taweret, the hippopotamus goddess of fertility, childbirth, and protection, is identified as a draconian mother dragon figure, corresponding to the constellation Draco and linked to Tiamat. A 3-day ritual series focuses on connecting with her: 'Celestial Gnosis' (contacting the great mother dragon at the North Pole through Merkabah visualization for wisdom), 'Celestial Timing' (hourly prayers and an invocation for cosmic journeys and visions through dreams), and 'Celestial Birth' (invoking Taweret's fertility to manifest a creative project, promising public praise upon completion, with a blood anointing). This provides a macrocosmic link to personal initiatic processes.

Sopdet, the personification of Sirius, is presented as a curious neter central to the draconian period, important for the ancient Egyptian calendar and agriculture, with ties to the Dogon tribe. From a Left Hand Path perspective, she is associated with the 'Black Sun' (Thagirion/Baphomet). A solitary ritual, 'First Contact,' is provided to connect with Sirius's energy for revitalization and gnosis, involving chanting 'Sopdet' and visualizing a merger with the Milky Way and Sirius for an altered state of void consciousness.

Tehuti (Thoth), the ibis-headed god of magic, wisdom, timekeeping, writing, and communication, is highlighted as a lunar neter from draconian times and a record keeper working with Ma'at. A 2-day ritual system focuses on communication: 'Channeled Writing' (anointing Tehuti's image with blood and chanting 'Tehuti un-na!' to receive channeled transmissions) and 'Instigated Communication' (chanting 'Tehuti per' to initiate conscious writing for guidance on personal growth and future focus). This system serves as a template for ongoing dialogue.

Amun, the 'hidden one,' is explored as a draconian deity pre-dating Ra and Khepra, representing the concealed and unknown, the original hidden god before light. A 3-day ritual aims to develop 'dark sight' and access hidden gnosis: 'Facing the Shadow Watcher' (pathworking to observe a hidden ritual at twilight on the Nile's banks), 'Forbidden Gnosis' (executing the ritual received on Day 1), and 'Navigating the Nightside' (scrying into a black mirror/bowl of water while chanting 'Senef iw akh' to receive messages from Amun and explore the Qabalistic tree of nightside pools).

Sobek, the crocodile deity, is analyzed for his draconian aspects, representing protection (especially from the Nile), military skill, cunning, fertility, and prosperity, with a fluid, adaptable nature. His connection to Set through passions is noted. A 3-day ritual focuses on emotional transformation: 'Evoker of Passions' (purging negative emotions by spitting into a chalice as an offering to Sobek), 'Purification through Water' (scrying into red wine mixed with purged emotions to visualize a perfected, immortal form), and 'Shedding Skin' (invoking Sobek for blessings of prosperity and new beginnings by 'drinking' spirit from an empty chalice).

This chapter explores the scorpion thoughtform in ancient Egypt, acknowledging its duality from kings (Scorpion I & II) representing power and harm, to the goddess Serqet representing beneficence. A 3-day ritual aims to awaken and integrate this dormant energy for personal empowerment: 'First Contact' (summoning the scorpion spirit with libation to build immunity to harm), 'Awakening the Scorpion' (integrating scorpion power into one's being), and 'Venom Control' (electrifying one's blood with scorpion venom to neutralize toxic situations and empower magical work, directing it as a stream of acid).

Wadjet, the cobra-headed goddess, protector of Lower Egypt, is examined for her draconian nature, representing life, fertility, duality ('two becoming one'), and the venom's dual power (kill/heal), linked to the Uraeus symbol of lineage. A 3-day ritual focuses on self-discovery and authority: 'Oracle of Wadjet' (scrying through incense smoke to receive answers to life questions), 'Merging the Two into One' (writing a personal decree to heal the rift with the shadow self), and 'Coronation' (assuming one's lineage and authority under Wadjet's protection, involving crown placement, anointing, and sexual arousal/climax for energetic cloaking).

Nekhbet, the white vulture goddess, protector of Southern Egypt and 'mother of mothers,' is explored for her connections to prophecy, divination, necromancy, and purification, placing her in the same category as Taweret. A 3-day ritual focuses on leadership and spiritual insight: 'Divination' (scrying in a black bowl of water while chanting 'muu' for images), 'Coronation' (claiming one's birthright and protection under Nekhbet's reign, placing a headdress on the head), and 'The Pledge' (writing and consecrating a personal decree with blood, then burning it to manifest new life changes, modeled after a ruler's command).

Nebet-Het (Nephthys), the dark goddess of the night sky, nocturnal initiation, and funerary rites, is analyzed beyond her misunderstood modern correspondences. She is part of an 'unholy trinity' with Aset and Anpu, teaching Anpu dark arts and death magic, and is linked to Set as his consort. A 3-day ritual explores her draconian nature: 'Initiation' (invoking Nebet-Het for necrotic wisdom and ancient Egyptian secrets through vision), 'Sacrifice' (burning a written sacrifice of a habit or relationship), and 'Anointing' (receiving a divine mark from Nebet-Het with sacred oil as a 'passport' into draconian magical mysteries).

The epilogue summarizes the book as a primer to the draconian Egyptian epoch, emphasizing its focus on the African roots of Egyptian magic and the foundational nature of these ancient spiritual truths. It highlights the book's role in filling gaps in conventional thought and promises future works (e.g., 'Sat En Anpu'). It reinforces that the holistic understanding presented is a beginning to deeper spiritual truths and the true foundation of the Western world's philosophies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix A: Creation of a Sabti
structure_content.summary: This appendix details the concept of a sabti (shabti/ushabti), a small statue traditionally placed in tombs to perform functions for the deceased. The ritual described adapts this practice for a living practitioner, creating an 'invisible helper' imbued with a specific intent. It involves acquiring or making a figurine, recording its details, and activating it through a 'Sabti Ritual' (clearing space, directing 'dragon of the void' energy, declaring intent, chanting 'Heka Vovin!' and 'senk her-s'), followed by an 'Opening of the Mouth Ceremony' (invoking Ptah, Thoth, Atum, Wadjet, Sahyt, and purifying with smoke, salt, water, and fire) to bring the sabti to life.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix B: Nine Parts of the Egyptian Soul
structure_content.summary: This appendix provides a detailed breakdown of the nine components of the Egyptian soul, acknowledging its development over various time periods. The parts are: Khat (physical body, requiring preservation for afterlife), Khaibit (etheric double/energetic body), Ba (personality/waking consciousness, surviving death), Ka (vital essence/subconscious, fed by offerings), Aumakhua/Khua (oversoul/superconscious mind, containing all lifetimes' experiences, suggesting dual souls), Manna (vital force/prana of the soul), Ren (magical/secret name), Ib (heart, both incarnated and accumulated experiences, weighed in the afterlife), and Sheut (shadow self, repressed aspects/negative patterns, acknowledging duality).

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix C: Necromancy in Draconian Egypt
structure_content.summary: This essay explores necromancy in pre-dynastic draconian Egypt (c. 3850 BCE), linking it to the lunar-yoni paradigm and African spiritual traditions of spirit interaction and sacrifice. It highlights Anpu as the god of death and embalming, and Nebet-Het as the mistress of funerary rites, who worked in tandem. The essay discusses the metaphysical view of death as an initiation, reducing the fear factor and implying that post-mortem contact was not considered sinister. It also touches on the use of sabtis, the importance of developing clairvoyant skills ('speaking with the dead'), and specific oils and herbs (lotus, frankincense, myrrh) used in these meticulous, energetically charged practices.

A visual timeline chart illustrating key historical periods and events from Nabta Playa (17,000 BCE) through the end of the Ice Age (11,000 BCE), the Creation of the Sphinx (10,500 BCE), the Draconian/Typhonian Egypt era (10,500 - 3800 BCE), and Pre-Dynastic Egypt (2600 BCE).

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix E: The Nomes of This Time
structure_content.summary: A reference list of the Nomes (provinces/villages) of Upper and Lower Egypt during the later draconian period. Each Nome's Egyptian name, English translation, and associated deity (if known, such as Set, Horus, Sobek, Wadjet, Anubis, Min, Tehuti, Nekhbet) are provided. It discusses the significance of these animal-patroned regions and clarifies lesser-known deities like Unut (hare goddess) and Satis (antelope goddess) and their roles within this early pantheon, noting Hoor's (Horus) intentional exclusion due to his solar-phallic associations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix F: Rulers of These Times
structure_content.summary: This appendix lists late pre-dynastic rulers of Upper and Lower Egypt, emphasizing their position prior to the unification of the two lands and the rise of the solar-phallic paradigm. Notable rulers mentioned include Elephant, Bull, Scorpion I (credited with early hieroglyphs), Iry-Hor (earliest known ruler by name, aligned with Hoor), Ka, and Scorpion II. The Palermo Stone's list of seven predynastic Lower Egyptian kings (Hsekiu, Khayu, Tiu, Thesh, Neheb, Wazner, Mekh) is also included, with an acknowledgment of the limited information available on them. The section concludes with a list of authors for further research in the Draconian Tradition and ancient Egypt.

key_concepts.definition: A magical path primarily rooted in ancient Egypt, inspired by symbolism from mythological dragons and serpents, linked to primal forces (like Ta-Urt/Taweret and Apep/Leviathan) existing within nature, the human body, and the soul. In this book, it refers specifically to a pre-dynastic Egyptian era (c. 10,500 – 3800 BCE) characterized by lunar-yoni energies, Setian forces, and African spirit traditions, before the rise of the solar-phallic paradigm.
A book containing instructions for magical rituals and spells, intended as a practical manual for practitioners.

Egyptian deities, viewed as personifications or animisms of raw forces of nature. They are considered the 'elders of the pantheon,' embodying natural forces, environments, and events, whose roles and popularities could wax, wane, or amalgamate over time.

The Egyptian afterlife, or the unmanifested realm where souls of the dead journey. Metaphysically, it also represents the dual side of physical existence, where the known is reflected in the unknown. The physical world is considered 'spiritual night,' and death is 'spiritual day' or initiation into one's true being.

Small statues, traditionally placed in Egyptian tombs, charged to perform specific functions for the mummy in the otherworld. In this book, the concept is adapted to create an 'invisible helper' or 'spirit' for a living practitioner, imbued with intent and activated through ritual.
A magical energy current associated with serpents and dragons, recognized as a significant influence on the spiritual development of draconian Egypt.

A spiritual and societal system emphasizing the sun and masculine energies, which rose to prominence in Egypt after the draconian era, marked by the rule of pharaoh Djedefre (c. 2613-2494 BCE) and the ascendancy of deities like Hoor (Horus).

The realm of hidden wisdom, gnosis, and deeper spiritual truths, accessible through working with certain deities (like Set and Nebet-Het), often associated with darkness, the unknown, and primal energies.

An Enochian word meaning 'dragon.' In the context of Taweret's ritual in this book, it is given a double entendre meaning of both 'dragon' and 'Manifestation,' used in chanting to emphasize the invocation and manifestation of the deity.

A sacred geometrical shape comprising two interlocking pyramids, used in ceremonial magic as a vehicle to manipulate one's light body to cross the abyss. It serves to protect the light body and mind during altered states of consciousness and astral travel.

A traditional ancient Egyptian ritual to activate a statue or 'shell' for a spirit to reside within it. In this book, a condensed version is used to imbue a created sabti with intent, bringing it to life for the practitioner.

Early administrative divisions or regions in pre-dynastic Egypt, essentially villages or encampments, each typically associated with a particular patron animal or fetish, which served as its protector spirit.
The ancient Egyptian term for magic or magical power. It is understood as a fundamental force in the universe, present in deities and rituals.

practical_system.description: The book serves as a practical grimoire, providing structured ritual sequences designed to facilitate direct contact and work with specific draconian Egyptian deities and thoughtforms. The system emphasizes self-initiation, personal gnosis, and empowerment by adapting ancient practices to modern contexts. Rituals often involve raising inner energy, chanting sacred words/phrases (often Egyptian or Enochian), visualization, blood anointing (optional), scrying, and the use of specific correspondences (incense, candles, oils). The 'Sabti Ritual' provides a method for creating personal servitor-like entities for practical magical assistance.

relevant_quotes.text: Magic in ancient Egypt included a wide spectrum of spells, religious practices, rituals, festivals, and traditions. It was intertwined with religion, and people prayed to the gods for protection and help in their daily life as well as performed spells and magical rituals to ensure that the gods will be favorable to their pleads.

What is also unique to this book is that it is written from the perspective of the Draconian Tradition and incorporates rituals that were originally designed for inner projects within the Temple of Ascending Flame.
The original Ouroboros - the serpent biting its tail - the leading symbol of the cycle of birth-death-rebirth.

The truth probably lies somewhere in the middle, and this is an important point to keep in mind when analyzing all material.
It is always the wisest to approach things from a space of love.

The easiest way to understand this is to think of it this way: What is it that spiritually fulfills you? If you are not being fulfilled on that level, then your Manna is depleted and you are spiritually hungry.
Necromancy breaks down to 'speaking with the dead,' so in order to speak to them, we must first develop our skills in order to accomplish this.
At its roots, the draconian Egyptian tradition is founded in African traditions, and anything past the draconian period is an improvement upon that system.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant to practitioners interested in the historical and operative aspects of Egyptian magic, particularly those within the Left Hand Path or Draconian Tradition. It fills a niche by focusing on the pre-dynastic 'draconian' era, which often receives less attention than later dynastic periods. By grounding Egyptian magic in its proposed African tribal roots and contextualizing it within celestial cycles and geopolitical shifts, the author offers a unique and foundational perspective. The integration of modern magical techniques with ancient symbolism provides an accessible yet profound system for self-initiation, gnosis, and personal empowerment, challenging conventional Egyptological views and deepening the understanding of esoteric currents.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes advanced practitioners and serious students of Western Esotericism, Occultism, Left Hand Path, Chaos Magic, Thelema, Qabalah, and those with a particular interest in Draconian Tradition or ancient Egyptian magic. It is also suitable for individuals seeking practical, self-initiatory magical systems for personal transformation and empowerment. Familiarity with Kenneth Grant's works, basic occult terminology, and ritual practice is beneficial for optimal engagement with the material.
